items.title: Restructuring project permissions
items.body:
#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [x] Other

Need write permissions for a separate branch to work on restructuring.

As of now, not much code but, I've got my ideas straight. Look up the current work [here](https://github.com/Mikhail-Zex/spotify-downloader).

items.title: I can't find a way to change default download location permanently.
items.body:
[X] Bug

I updated spotdl after 5 months now (everything was going smoothly before), and for some reason my music kept being downloaded. Before the latest update, my spotdl default directory was completely fine. It pointed to the right Music folder (instead of System32), and I didn't need to change anything.
But now, I tried searching every corner of this GitHub to find a permanent solution (whether it's modifying my config.yml file) to change the default directory, but no luck. Although this is nothing more than a little nuisance for me right now, I really hope that they would include a solution at the very top of [spotdl readthedocs.io](https://spotdl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/download-tracks.html) on how to change the default folder, or at least in the [Advanced Usage](https://spotdl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced-usage.html) page.
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36707936/87512411-cf2dcc80-c62b-11ea-80d8-f227b69b8304.png)
(screenshot for reference, d30.txt is the playlist that I just downloaded, and had to transfer all of the music files into my ACTUAL music folder. Even the --playlist text files are being created in my System32 folder,)

items.title: Option to specify youtube video ( besides manual )
items.body:
#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [ ] Bug
- [X] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
Currently, if a specific video url is not present in the search results returned by -m, you have to mess around with the search format. Instead, an option that allows you to speficy a specific video url from the cli would be great. Example usage could be:
`spotdl --song {whatever} --youtube {youtube link to song}`.
Besides the use case used above, this could also be used to skip searching through the search results for a specific video in the first place.

items.title: Where does spotdl look for ffmpeg?
items.body:
I've been trying to run spotdl in Linux on a Chromebook. After many attempts and coding, it finally worked, although it won't convert spotify's ".obu" files into the .mp3 format. Every time I download a playlist, it displays `FFmpeg was not found in PATH. Will not re-encode media to specified output format` 

I'm trying to figure out where spotdl looks for ffmpeg so i can change my ffmpeg's location there. I already download ffmpeg using `pip install ffmpeg`.

Any ideas?

items.title: AttributeError: 'ArgumentHandler' object has no attribute 'parser'
items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [x ] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
When using the -f args in the command line for downloading a playlist, an error is occuring saying  

Example of command used. In bold the argument which creates the error
spotdl --list ./PlaylistSpotdl/playlistName.txt -o m4a **-f "./Music/playlistName"** --write-successful "./Music/playlistName/_downloadedfiles.txt" --skip "./Music/playlistName/_downloadedfiles.txt" --overwrite skip
```console
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\users\vhavard\appdata\local\continuum\anaconda3\envs\spotdl\lib\runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "c:\users\vhavard\appdata\local\continuum\anaconda3\envs\spotdl\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "C:\Users\vhavard\AppData\Local\Continuum\anaconda3\envs\spotdl\Scripts\spotdl.exe\__main__.py", line 7, in <module>
  File "c:\users\vhavard\appdata\local\continuum\anaconda3\envs\spotdl\lib\site-packages\spotdl\command_line\__main__.py", line 24, in main
    with Spotdl(args) as spotdl_handler:
  File "c:\users\vhavard\appdata\local\continuum\anaconda3\envs\spotdl\lib\site-packages\spotdl\command_line\core.py", line 38, in __init__
    arguments = argument_handler.run_errands()
  File "c:\users\vhavard\appdata\local\continuum\anaconda3\envs\spotdl\lib\site-packages\spotdl\command_line\arguments.py", line 364, in run_errands
    self.parser.get_default("output_file")
AttributeError: 'ArgumentHandler' object has no attribute 'parser'
```

Without, this -f args, everything is working as it should.  

### possible fix
Adding this code in the ArgumentsHandler class make it works fine for me
``` python
class ArgumentHandler:
    def __init__(self, args={}, config_base=_CONFIG_BASE):
        self.config_base = config_base
        self.args = args
        self.configured_args = self._from_args(args)
        # Fixed by VHD
        self.parser = get_arguments()
``` 

### Log
<!-- Run the script with `--log-level=DEBUG` and paste the output below-->

items.title: Incorrect filename: "Token - YouTube Rapper - Bonus"
items.body:
#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [ x ] Bug
- [ x ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

When specifying a specific youtube url - it sometimes gets completely the wrong filename. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WL8haXrw4QA  is a charlotte de witte track - that gets named to a Beyonce track

I suspect this is because it is going to spotify to get the details or it's doing some search. Is it possible that it be specified to just take the the data from the youtube title?

items.body:
Hi,
After updated to new version spotdl 2.0.9, realized that spotdl doesn't download on specified folder in config.yml, everything was fine before update to new version.
It downloads everything in root.

items.title: Redirecting logger buffer to string / variable.
items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [x] Question
- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Other
- [ ] Feature Request

### Description
#### What would be the best way to redirect the logger information?

I have tried to override the `logger` variable in the main `command_line` file and tested a few things but it overrides it completely and wont log information to the terminal when used.  I am working on a GUI for myself to use and just curious if anyone knows a better way.

Currently I am redirecting to StringIO and using the logger.getValue to set information in the GUI.

I was thinking about adding a second logger and trying to have it both output to the terminal and also to string but I figured I would ask to see if someone had a better idea before I do that.

Keep in mind this is my first big python project and I'm using it as a way to learn.  I really don't mind if a new release will break what I have now... just messing around.

A basic example of what I'm doing:
```
import logging
from io import StringIO
logBuffer = StringIO()    
logging.basicConfig(stream=logBuffer, level=logging.NOTSET)
logging.getLogger().addFilter(LevelFilter((logging.INFO, logging.WARNING, logging.ERROR)))

#logger.info etc used

print(logBuffer.getvalue())

```

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI

  including closed ones.
-->

<!--

items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [x] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
Hello, spotdl was working perfectly yesterday. Today when I went to use it, it does not work on both of my computers (running Zorin OS - based on Ubuntu). No downloads are going through (song, playlist, album, etc...)

EDIT: [I just tried on Elementary OS and Solus as well and no luck. It seems to be a non-user related problem. Also, Issue #740 describes what seems to be the same problem. The OP of #740 thinks it is related to something he did but I suspect not because the problem is occurring across multiple distros and with multiple users.]

EDIT 2: [I also just want to mention that I hadn't used my second computer (with Zorin) since 2 days ago, and spotdl worked perfectly. Today, when spotdl wouldn't download anything on my primary computer, I tried it on my secondary (I assumed I must have done something to break it). But again, I'm convinced it is not a user problem because it didn't work on my secondary computer either (nor on a freshly installed Elementary OS or Solus), when the last thing I did with it 2 days ago was download some songs with spotdl.]

I tried looking at the code for extract.py and __main__.py but was not able to determine the problem. Then, I updated & upgraded all packages (snap, pip, apt). I tried downloading songs, albums, playalists, etc... None are working. 

When downloading a playlist or album, it does successfully create the .txt file with all the URLs to the individual songs but when attempting to download from the file with spotdl -l (or even trying one song at a time), it brings back the error shown below (in the log). 

### Log

items.title: KeyError: 'cipher': Most tracks fail to download
items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [x] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description

When I try to download a playlist spotdl will download one song and then crash.

I generated a playlist .txt file using the spodl --playlist command, but when I run the spotdl --list command only one song will download. Then the entire program will crash after attempting to fetch the metadata of the next song. Running the command again immediatly crashes and shows the same errors.

If I wait for a few minutes before running the command, it will again download one song and crash after attempting to fetch the metadata of the next song.


### Log
<details>
<summary>
$ spotdl --list well-this-is-me.txt -ll debug
</summary>

items.title: Downloading songs manually and then skipping a song using 0 (zero) crashes the script
items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [x] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
In the config.yml file I set song downloading to "manual: true". The song downloader works with numbers 1 through 10, but skipping the song with 0 (zero) crashes the script it seems. 
Using the "-m" tag in the command window does the same thing.
It's not the biggest hassle as doing it manually you can simply relaunch the script and all is well.

Probably my final bug report so thanks again for making this awesome, insanely useful program. Apologies if this was a matter of installing somethign falsely.

### Log
<!-- Run the script with `--log-level=DEBUG` and paste the output below-->
https://pastebin.com/sp5T4Pmg

items.title: Add "explicit" tag value to output metadata
items.body:
#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [ ] Bug
- [X] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description

Hi, would it be possible to add the "explicit" tag value from the Spotify track to the metadata of the output file? I know that .m4a supports this tag at least. 

It would be very useful in using with Apple/Google Music so that it gets the right version of the song...

Thanks!

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
I noticed that the script uses the "subprocess.call(command)" yet "subprocess.run(command)" is way faster and recommended in the official python docs. @ritiek maybe you can refactor this, it's just a simple Find and Replace issue

<!-- Run the script with `--log-level=DEBUG` and paste the output below-->

items.title: Does anyone use `--no-fallback-metadata` and `--download-only-metadata`?
items.body: Like the title says, have you guys ever had a use for these flags? I've personally never used them and don't think others find them useful either. I plan on removing them in the next release v2.0.0 if there aren't many people who use them.

items.title: Specify YouTube URL
items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [ ] Bug
- [x] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
I wish there was a way to specify what video you wanted to pull the audio from, that was different from the `-m` option. something like this:
`spotdl -s spotify:track:1qxcyvBOcu3wnZpxlihnBf -y https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3QHX7Q9rfno`
I have done this song with the `-m` option, and the right song doesn't show up so I end up having to tweak the search terms in the config.yml. It would be great to be able to choose the song from Spotify for the metadata, and also choose the YouTube video.

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
So I enabled music-videos only in my config.yml file and generated a youtube API. I quicky used up all my api requests quota, and that got me thinking. There needs to be a feature for generating multiple API-keys and adding them to the config file separate by commas. items.title: what/where is the spotify 'http link' described in the readme?
items.body:
<!--
Please follow the guide below

- Before opening your ticket, make sure you either installed the latest release from PyPI
  or installed directly from the master branch and have searched through existing issues
  including closed ones.
-->

<!--
- Put an `x` into the box [ ] below (like [x]) depending on the purpose of your issue
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your issue will actually look like
-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [ ] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [x] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description

From the readme: "Downloads songs from YouTube in an MP3 format by using Spotify's HTTP link."

I seem to recall reading from the Spotify API docs that you can (often) get an actual youtube url/id for a given spotify track, but I can't seem to find it.

I'm not seeing it in the 'Tracks' API docs...

https://developer.spotify.com/documentation/web-api/reference/tracks/

... and I'm not seeing it in generate_metadata(),,,

https://github.com/ritiek/spotify-downloader/blob/937ed6ebcc6c57185b30499f243091c32eafc58b/spotdl/spotify_tools.py#L45

Spotify devs confirm here that external_urls only ever contains a spotify url.

https://github.com/spotify/web-api/issues/1050

So where in the Spotify API is this 'http link' that spotify-downloader uses? Or does spotify-downloader just rely on youtube searches for artist/album?

Thanks much.

items.title: Randomly occurring errno 2
items.body:
#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [X] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
There isn't much to tell, an error along the lines of
```
mutagen.MutagenError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: "C:\\dir\\to\\song.mp3"
```
happens for no explicit reason, and rerunning the script fixes it, so the only way to replicate it is through pure chance.

### Log
Again, I can't get the debug info because I don't know when it will happen. Just try downloading a large playlist, it's probably gonna happen

items.body: I've noticed that all the songs i've downloaded so far are 192kbs, is it possible to get them at maybe 256 or 320 ?

items.title: Argument output-ext is ineffective and music is downloaded as .m4a
items.body:

-->

#### What is the purpose of your *issue*?
- [x] Bug
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Question
- [ ] Other

### Description
<!-- Provide as much information possible and whatever you have tried below -->
When I enter the argument `--output-ext .mp3` to download a music as .mp3, the extension is still .m4a.
This is the complete command : 
`user@User-PC:~/Desktop$ spotdl -l list.txt --output-ext .mp3`
I know the _ffmpeg_ is missing and it's the reason why the conversion failed but if _ffmpeg_ is missing, maybe it's because the setup doesn't correctly install it.
Please, note that after using the command `sudo apt-get install ffmpeg`, the download as .mp3 works perfectly.
